case.name: Shek v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 522 (8 May 2006)

citances.sentence: The question arises in this case as to whether an applicant can have his visa cancelled for breach of a condition of that visa when the conduct occurred under a previously held visa. The Tribunal notes the decision of Shek v MIMIA [2006] FCA 522 may be seen to have some application but, unlike that case, in this instance there is no overlap of conduct between the two visas. The conduct in question occurred wholly during the period of the first visa.

The reality is that the section 116 cancellation is not constrained or affected by the cancellation power under section 137J , initiated by a section 20 notice, and in that regard, the subject Tribunal's decision stands aside from those considered in Humayun v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCAFC 35 ; Shek v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 522 ; and Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs v Zhou [2006] FCAFC 96.

If the visa is in force at the end of the term and the applicant was in fact enrolled at the commencement of the term, even if under a different visa, as is the case in this applciation, then an assessment can be made of whether there was compliance with the attendance condition of the visa which was extant at the end of the term: Shek [2006] FCA 522 at [32] .

In Shek v MIMIA [2006] FCA 522 , the wording of Condition 8202 was considered and it was found that the assessment of compliance with the condition requires an assessment to be made of attendance over the duration of 'each term'.

He submits that this application for review of the Tribunal decision is about a cancellation of the student visa under s.116. The cancellation power under s.116 is separate to, and cannot be constrained by, the cancellation power under s.137J which is initiated by a s.20 Notice. This is made clear in the Full Federal Court decisions of Humayun v Minister for Immigration [2006] FCAFC 35 ( Humayun ); Minister for Immigration v Zhou [2006] FCAFC 96 ( Zhou ); Shek v Minister for Immigration [2006] FCA 522 ( Shek ). It is submitted that the only relationship between s.137J and s.116 is the factual basis which grounds the cancellation. In Zhou , the Court accepted the Minister's argument that "a mere factual, casual, connection between a s.20 notice and the initiation of the cancellation process under s.116 of the Act cannot affect the validity of a decision mandated by the latter section": at [27].

The Tribunal notes that in Shek v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 522 (8 May 2006) Siopis J held that subclause 8202(3)(a)(ii), which is the current equivalent of subclause 8202(3)(c)(ii) which is before the Tribunal, provides that where a course runs for at least a semester the attendance requirement is necessary for each term or semester of the course. The legislation, policy and other materials that are immediately relevant to this review are: Legislation:
Item 1222 of Schedule 1 to the Regulations
Part 572 of Schedule 2 to the Regulations
Migration Legislation Amendment (Overseas Students) Act 2000
Condition 8202 of Schedule 8 to the Regulations
Departmental policy:
Procedures Advice Manual 3: Generic Guidelines G - Student visas
Cases:
Kim v Witton [1995] FCA 1508 ; (1995) 59 FCR 258
Baidakova v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [1998] FCA 1436
Pradhan v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [1999] FCA 1240 ; (1999) 94 FCR 91
Kwan v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2002] FCA 498
Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs v Kwan [2002] FCAFC 380
Gurung v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs [2002] FCA 772
Woo v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2002] FCA 1596
Siddique v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2003] FCAFC 16
Weerasinghe v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs [2004] FCA 261
Tian v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs [2004] FCA 216
Quan v Minister for Immigration, Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2004] FCA 764
Tian v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affair s [2004] FCAFC 238
SZBAZ v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2004] FMCA 790
Mehdi v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2005] FMCA 1160
SZDQO v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2005] FCA 1026
SZFIH v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2005] FMCA 1847
Wickramasinghe v Minister for Immigration & Anor [2005] FMCA 1558
Mehdi v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 498
Shek v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 522 (8 May 2006)
SZFKD & Anor v Minister for Immigration & Anor [2006] FMCA [2006] 49
SZCDH v Minister for Immigration & Anor [2006] FMCA 78 The Tribunal generally has regard to the Regulations as they stood at the time of a visa application.

The Full Court's decision in Humayun v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (2006) FCAFC 35 was recently followed and applied by Siopsis J in Shek v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (2006) FCA 522 at (41) to (45).
30 The Full Court decision in Humayun was recently followed and applied by Siopis J in Shek v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 522 at [41] - [45].
